_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention
Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.
Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of their regulated substance.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility is located at 4401 Foxdale Ave, Irwindale CA, 91706.

The regulated substance managed at the facility is anhydrous ammonia. 

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: RMP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the Ammonia Refrigeration System. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the CalARP/EPA RMP/ CalOSHA PSM Program Level 3 Compliance Workbook.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: An alternative release scenario was modeled. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the CalARP/EPA RMP/ CalOSHA PSM Program Level 3 Compliance Workbook.

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible. In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should
also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actua

lly be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an
ammonia release:
Well-designed Relief System
Safety Showers/Eyewash Stations
Gas Detection

Accidental Release Prevention Program
As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia. Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to
ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facility maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 49,347 lbs. Therefore, the regulated substance is over the 10,000 lbs threshold for EPA RMP and the Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities and over the 500 lbs state threshold for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program. As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to RMP Program Level 3.

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:
Process Safety Information (PSI)
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
Operating Procedures (OP)
Training (TRN)
Mechanical Integrity (MI)
Management of Change (MOC)
Pre-Startup Review (PSSR)
Compliance Audits (CA)
Incident Investigation (II)
Employee Participation (EP)
Hot Work Permit (HWP)
Contractors (CON)
Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no RMP-applicable releases of ammonia at the Facility in the past five years, as February 2012.

Emergency Response Program
Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility has implemented an Emergenc

y Action Plan (EAP) and does not assume the role of first responder during an emergency. has filed a Hazardous Materials Business Plan with the City of Los Angeles Fire Department and this plan includes:
Emergency Alarm Procedures
Evacuation Procedures
Safety and Health Considerations
Notification Procedure
The Emergency Action Plan meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 §3220.
Planned Changes To Improve Safety
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the January 10th, 2007 PHA Report located behind the Process Hazard Analysis Tab of the CalARP/EPA RMP/CalOSHA PSM
Program Level 3 Workbook. Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by February 2013.

Flammables: Worst Case
The use of flammable materials at Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or
state RMP requirements. Therefore, this section is not applicable.

Flammables: Alternative Release
The use of flammable materials at Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or
state RMP requirements. Therefore, this section is not applicable.
